trans-unit.source: Styles let you set control properties and reuse those settings for a consistent appearance across multiple controls.
trans-unit.target: Styles let you set control properties and reuse those settings for a consistent appearance across multiple controls.

trans-unit.source: Styling controls
trans-unit.target: Styling controls

trans-unit.source: Styling controls
trans-unit.target: Styling controls

trans-unit.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]
trans-unit.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]

trans-unit.source: You can customize the appearance of your apps in many ways by using the XAML framework.
trans-unit.target: You can customize the appearance of your apps in many ways by using the XAML framework.

trans-unit.source: Styles let you set control properties and reuse those settings for a consistent appearance across multiple controls.
trans-unit.target: Styles let you set control properties and reuse those settings for a consistent appearance across multiple controls.

trans-unit.source: Style basics
trans-unit.target: Style basics

trans-unit.source: Use styles to extract visual property settings into reusable resources.
trans-unit.target: Use styles to extract visual property settings into reusable resources.

trans-unit.source: Here's an example that shows 3 buttons with a style that sets the [**BorderBrush**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209397), [**BorderThickness**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209399) and [**Foreground**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209414) properties.
trans-unit.target: Here's an example that shows 3 buttons with a style that sets the [**BorderBrush**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209397), [**BorderThickness**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209399) and [**Foreground**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209414) properties.

trans-unit.source: By applying a style, you can make the controls appear the same without having to set these properties on each control separately.
trans-unit.target: By applying a style, you can make the controls appear the same without having to set these properties on each control separately.

trans-unit.source: styled buttons
trans-unit.target: styled buttons

trans-unit.source: You can define a style inline in the XAML for a control, or as a reusable resource.
trans-unit.target: You can define a style inline in the XAML for a control, or as a reusable resource.

trans-unit.source: Define resources in an individual page's XAML file, in the App.xaml file, or in a separate resource dictionary XAML file.
trans-unit.target: Define resources in an individual page's XAML file, in the App.xaml file, or in a separate resource dictionary XAML file.

trans-unit.source: A resource dictionary XAML file can be shared across apps, and more than one resource dictionary can be merged in a single app.
trans-unit.target: A resource dictionary XAML file can be shared across apps, and more than one resource dictionary can be merged in a single app.

trans-unit.source: Where the resource is defined determines the scope in which it can be used.
trans-unit.target: Where the resource is defined determines the scope in which it can be used.

trans-unit.source: Page-level resources are available only in the page where they are defined.
trans-unit.target: Page-level resources are available only in the page where they are defined.

trans-unit.source: If resources with the same key are defined in both App.xaml and in a page, the resource in the page overrides the resource in App.xaml.
trans-unit.target: If resources with the same key are defined in both App.xaml and in a page, the resource in the page overrides the resource in App.xaml.

trans-unit.source: If a resource is defined in a separate resource dictionary file, it's scope is determined by where the resource dictionary is referenced.
trans-unit.target: If a resource is defined in a separate resource dictionary file, it's scope is determined by where the resource dictionary is referenced.

trans-unit.source: In the [**Style**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208849) definition, you need a [**TargetType**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208857) attribute and a collection of one or more [**Setter**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208817) elements.
trans-unit.target: In the [**Style**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208849) definition, you need a [**TargetType**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208857) attribute and a collection of one or more [**Setter**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208817) elements.

trans-unit.source: The **TargetType** attribute is a string that specifies a [**FrameworkElement**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208706) type to apply the style to.
trans-unit.target: The **TargetType** attribute is a string that specifies a [**FrameworkElement**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208706) type to apply the style to.

trans-unit.source: The **TargetType** value must specify a **FrameworkElement**-derived type that's defined by the Windows Runtime or a custom type that's available in a referenced assembly.
trans-unit.target: The **TargetType** value must specify a **FrameworkElement**-derived type that's defined by the Windows Runtime or a custom type that's available in a referenced assembly.

trans-unit.source: If you try to apply a style to a control and the control's type doesn't match the **TargetType** attribute of the style you're trying to apply, an exception occurs.
trans-unit.target: If you try to apply a style to a control and the control's type doesn't match the **TargetType** attribute of the style you're trying to apply, an exception occurs.

trans-unit.source: Each [**Setter**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208817) element requires a [**Property**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208836) and a [**Value**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208838).
trans-unit.target: Each [**Setter**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208817) element requires a [**Property**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208836) and a [**Value**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208838).

trans-unit.source: These property settings indicate what control property the setting applies to, and the value to set for that property.
trans-unit.target: These property settings indicate what control property the setting applies to, and the value to set for that property.

trans-unit.source: You can set the **Setter.Value** with either attribute or property element syntax.
trans-unit.target: You can set the **Setter.Value** with either attribute or property element syntax.

trans-unit.source: The XAML here shows the style applied to the buttons shown previously.
trans-unit.target: The XAML here shows the style applied to the buttons shown previously.

trans-unit.source: In this XAML, the first two **Setter** elements use attribute syntax, but the last **Setter**, for the [**BorderBrush**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209397) property, uses property element syntax.
trans-unit.target: In this XAML, the first two **Setter** elements use attribute syntax, but the last **Setter**, for the [**BorderBrush**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209397) property, uses property element syntax.

trans-unit.source: The example doesn't use the [x:Key attribute](../xaml-platform/x-key-attribute.md) attribute, so the style is implicitly applied to the buttons.
trans-unit.target: The example doesn't use the [x:Key attribute](../xaml-platform/x-key-attribute.md) attribute, so the style is implicitly applied to the buttons.

trans-unit.source: Applying styles implicitly or explicitly is explained in the next section.
trans-unit.target: Applying styles implicitly or explicitly is explained in the next section.

trans-unit.source: Apply an implicit or explicit style
trans-unit.target: Apply an implicit or explicit style

trans-unit.source: If you define a style as a resource, there are two ways to apply it to your controls:
trans-unit.target: If you define a style as a resource, there are two ways to apply it to your controls:

trans-unit.source: Implicitly, by specifying only a [**TargetType**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208857) for the [**Style**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208849).
trans-unit.target: Implicitly, by specifying only a [**TargetType**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208857) for the [**Style**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208849).

trans-unit.source: Explicitly, by specifying a [**TargetType**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208857) and an [x:Key attribute](../xaml-platform/x-key-attribute.md) attribute for the [**Style**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208849) and then by setting the target control's [**Style**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208743) property with a [{StaticResource} markup extension](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/mt185588) reference that uses the explicit key.
trans-unit.target: Explicitly, by specifying a [**TargetType**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208857) and an [x:Key attribute](../xaml-platform/x-key-attribute.md) attribute for the [**Style**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208849) and then by setting the target control's [**Style**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208743) property with a [{StaticResource} markup extension](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/mt185588) reference that uses the explicit key.

trans-unit.source: If a style contains the [x:Key attribute](../xaml-platform/x-key-attribute.md), you can only apply it to a control by setting the [**Style**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208743) property of the control to the keyed style.
trans-unit.target: If a style contains the [x:Key attribute](../xaml-platform/x-key-attribute.md), you can only apply it to a control by setting the [**Style**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208743) property of the control to the keyed style.

trans-unit.source: In contrast, a style without an x:Key attribute is automatically applied to every control of its target type, that doesn't otherwise have an explicit style setting.
trans-unit.target: In contrast, a style without an x:Key attribute is automatically applied to every control of its target type, that doesn't otherwise have an explicit style setting.

trans-unit.source: Here are two buttons that demonstrate implicit and explicit styles.
trans-unit.target: Here are two buttons that demonstrate implicit and explicit styles.

trans-unit.source: implicitly and explicitly styled buttons.
trans-unit.target: implicitly and explicitly styled buttons.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the first style has an [x:Key attribute](../xaml-platform/x-key-attribute.md) and its target type is [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209265).
trans-unit.target: In this example, the first style has an [x:Key attribute](../xaml-platform/x-key-attribute.md) and its target type is [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209265).

trans-unit.source: The first button's [**Style**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208743) property is set to this key, so this style is applied explicitly.
trans-unit.target: The first button's [**Style**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208743) property is set to this key, so this style is applied explicitly.

trans-unit.source: The second style is applied implicitly to the second button because its target type is **Button** and the style doesn't have an x:Key attribute.
trans-unit.target: The second style is applied implicitly to the second button because its target type is **Button** and the style doesn't have an x:Key attribute.

trans-unit.source: Use based-on styles
trans-unit.target: Use based-on styles

trans-unit.source: To make styles easier to maintain and to optimize style reuse, you can create styles that inherit from other styles.
trans-unit.target: To make styles easier to maintain and to optimize style reuse, you can create styles that inherit from other styles.

trans-unit.source: You use the [**BasedOn**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208852) property to create inherited styles.
trans-unit.target: You use the [**BasedOn**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208852) property to create inherited styles.

trans-unit.source: Styles that inherit from other styles must target the same type of control or a control that derives from the type targeted by the base style.
trans-unit.target: Styles that inherit from other styles must target the same type of control or a control that derives from the type targeted by the base style.

trans-unit.source: For example, if a base style targets [**ContentControl**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209365), styles that are based on this style can target **ContentControl** or types that derive from **ContentControl** such as [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209265) and [**ScrollViewer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209527).
trans-unit.target: For example, if a base style targets [**ContentControl**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209365), styles that are based on this style can target **ContentControl** or types that derive from **ContentControl** such as [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209265) and [**ScrollViewer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209527).

trans-unit.source: If a value is not set in the based-on style, it's inherited from the base style.
trans-unit.target: If a value is not set in the based-on style, it's inherited from the base style.

trans-unit.source: To change a value from the base style, the based-on style overrides that value.
trans-unit.target: To change a value from the base style, the based-on style overrides that value.

trans-unit.source: The next example shows a **Button** and a [**CheckBox**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209316) with styles that inherit from the same base style.
trans-unit.target: The next example shows a **Button** and a [**CheckBox**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209316) with styles that inherit from the same base style.

trans-unit.source: styled buttons usign based-on styles.
trans-unit.target: styled buttons usign based-on styles.

trans-unit.source: The base style targets [**ContentControl**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209365), and sets the [**Height**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208718), and [**Width**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208751) properties.
trans-unit.target: The base style targets [**ContentControl**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209365), and sets the [**Height**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208718), and [**Width**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208751) properties.

trans-unit.source: The styles based on this style target [**CheckBox**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209316) and [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209265), which derive from **ContentControl**.
trans-unit.target: The styles based on this style target [**CheckBox**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209316) and [**Button**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209265), which derive from **ContentControl**.

trans-unit.source: The based-on styles set different colors for the [**BorderBrush**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209397) and [**Foreground**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209414) properties.
trans-unit.target: The based-on styles set different colors for the [**BorderBrush**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209397) and [**Foreground**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209414) properties.

trans-unit.source: (You don't typically put a border around a **CheckBox**.
trans-unit.target: (You don't typically put a border around a **CheckBox**.

trans-unit.source: We do it here to show the effects of the style.)
trans-unit.target: We do it here to show the effects of the style.)

trans-unit.source: Use tools to work with styles easily
trans-unit.target: Use tools to work with styles easily

trans-unit.source: A fast way to apply styles to your controls is to right-click on a control on the Microsoft Visual Studio XAML design surface and select **Edit Style** or **Edit Template** (depending on the control you are right-clicking on).
trans-unit.target: A fast way to apply styles to your controls is to right-click on a control on the Microsoft Visual Studio XAML design surface and select **Edit Style** or **Edit Template** (depending on the control you are right-clicking on).

trans-unit.source: You can then apply an existing style by selecting **Apply Resource** or define a new style by selecting **Create Empty**.
trans-unit.target: You can then apply an existing style by selecting **Apply Resource** or define a new style by selecting **Create Empty**.

trans-unit.source: If you create an empty style, you are given the option to define it in the page, in the App.xaml file, or in a separate resource dictionary.
trans-unit.target: If you create an empty style, you are given the option to define it in the page, in the App.xaml file, or in a separate resource dictionary.

trans-unit.source: Modify the default system styles
trans-unit.target: Modify the default system styles

trans-unit.source: You should use the styles that come from the Windows Runtime default XAML resources when you can.
trans-unit.target: You should use the styles that come from the Windows Runtime default XAML resources when you can.

trans-unit.source: When you have to define your own styles, try to base your styles on the default ones when possible (using based-on styles as explained earlier, or start by editing a copy of the original default style).
trans-unit.target: When you have to define your own styles, try to base your styles on the default ones when possible (using based-on styles as explained earlier, or start by editing a copy of the original default style).

trans-unit.source: The Template property
trans-unit.target: The Template property

trans-unit.source: A style setter can be used for the [**Template**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209465) property of a [**Control**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209390), and in fact this makes up the majority of a typical XAML style and an app's XAML resources.
trans-unit.target: A style setter can be used for the [**Template**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209465) property of a [**Control**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br209390), and in fact this makes up the majority of a typical XAML style and an app's XAML resources.

trans-unit.source: This is discussed in more detail in the topic [Control templates](control-templates.md).
trans-unit.target: This is discussed in more detail in the topic [Control templates](control-templates.md).

trans-unit.source: Note
trans-unit.target: Note

trans-unit.source: This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
trans-unit.target: This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

trans-unit.source: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the [archived documentation](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132).
trans-unit.target: If you’re developing for Windows 8.x or Windows Phone 8.x, see the [archived documentation](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132).
